bioghist.p: Charles Mulford Robinson (1869-1917) was a journalist and specialist in town planning. He was the first Professor for Civic Design at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, which was only one of two universities offering courses in Urban Planning at the time. Robinson was a proponent of the City Beautiful movement and wrote The Fair of Spectacle, an illustrated description of Chicago's World Columbian Exposition in 1893. He went on to write The Improvement of Towns and Cities (1901), the first guide to city planning, among many other publications. He contributed to the planning of a number of American cities, including Denver, Omaha, Columbus, and Honolulu.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of professional and personal papers of Charles Mulford Robinson. Materials include correspondence; scrapbooks of clippings and notes; pamphlets; college class notes; and books. Professional materials include: reports to civic and business clubs and to planning commissions in a number of American cities, including Syracuse, New York, Hannibal, Missouri, St. Joseph, Missouri, Freeport, Illinois, Honolulu, Hawaii, and Greensboro, North Carolina; letters from civic and business clubs and planning commissions regarding his reports and proposals; and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings. Personal papers include manuscript orations, essays, and stories from Robinson's college years; a scrapbook of invitations and newspaper items about his marriage to Miss Eliza Ten Eyck Pruyn; a bible and books of poetry; a copper photograph plate of Mr. Robinson; a small batch of family papers related to Robinson's forbears; and correspondence with Mrs. Robinson, much of it related to the dedication of a memorial to Robinson at the University of Illinois.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
